data.name: Rolling Cylinder
data.description:
Given the mass and diameter of a solid cylinder, as well as the angle and height of a triangle, find the the time it would take for the cylinder to roll from the apex to the bottom of the triangle's hypotenuse. 

Steps:

    Determine the Triangle's Geometry:
        Angle (θ): The angle of the inclined plane with respect to the horizontal.
        Height (h): The vertical height from the base to the top.

    Cylinder's Properties:
        Diameter (D): The diameter of the cylinder.
        Radius (r): r = D / 2
        Mass (m): The mass of the cylinder.
        Moment of Inertia (I): For a solid cylinder, I = (1 / 2) m r^2

    Calculate the Inclined Plane's Length:
    The length of the hypotenuse of the triangle (L) can be found using the height and angle:
    L = h / sin⁡(θ)

    Find the Acceleration of the Cylinder:
    The acceleration aa of the cylinder rolling down the incline can be derived from the force of gravity and the rolling constraint:
    a = g sin⁡(θ) / (1 + I / (m r^2))

    For a solid cylinder:
    a = {g sin⁡(θ) / (1 + (((1/2) m r^2) / (m r^2)))} = {g sin⁡(θ) / (1 + 1/2)} = {2g sin⁡(θ) / 3}

    This formula is actually the same as for a solid disk because the moment of inertia is the same for a solid cylinder.

    Calculate the Time to Reach the End of the Triangle:
    Using the kinematic equation for constant acceleration:
    L = (1 / 2) a t^2

    Solve for tt:
    t = √(2L / a)
    
Tips:
- Make sure you convert to radians!

Specifications:
- If angle == 360, return a -1
- Round output to the hundredths place
- Assume gravity = 9.81
- Assume no slippage, no air resistance, or anything of the sort
- All inputs will be positive integers
